I thought the array has to be ordered in order for this to work. After looking into how bitwise XOR works, here is an example. 

it does the XOR operation on the bit representation of the number; 

8 => 1000
15 =>1111
8 ^ 15 = 7 => 0111
7 ^ 8 = 15 => 1111

You are welcome :)
Thanks!!
[@JaredMathis](/JaredMathis) but this way has problem of Runtime error
If the array is sorted, then the duplicates will be sequential. Therefore a number that was different on either side would be the answer.
emotional damage

The best solution is to use a bit shifting idea, which seems like it can be done in O(1). But, it can't. 

The integer used to hold the bits being canceled by the XORing must be large enough to contain all of the bits in the largest integer. So, if the largest integer needs only 2 bits, the additional memory can be 2 bits (plus the iterator/index counter). However, if the largest integer requires 100 bits, the the additional memory requires 100 bits. 

We know that numbers are not repeated more than once, so at worst case the nth number is n, which requires log2(n) bits to store. 

So, the extra memory required is actually at worst O(log(n))!

Note that if we use 32 bit integers (or really integers of any fixed size) as our tracking bits, we can pretend the memory used is constant - but really all we've done is allocated a lot of extra memory which happens to be enough.
why do you think this is the best solution? XOR\'s commutativity makes this possible with one stack allocation?
functools.reduce(operator.ixor, nums)

I thought the array has to be ordered in order for this to work. After looking into how bitwise XOR works, here is an example. 

it does the XOR operation on the bit representation of the number; 

8 => 1000
15 =>1111
8 ^ 15 = 7 => 0111
7 ^ 8 = 15 => 1111

You are welcome :)
Thanks!!
[@JaredMathis](/JaredMathis) but this way has problem of Runtime error
If the array is sorted, then the duplicates will be sequential. Therefore a number that was different on either side would be the answer.
emotional damage

The best solution is to use a bit shifting idea, which seems like it can be done in O(1). But, it can't. 

The integer used to hold the bits being canceled by the XORing must be large enough to contain all of the bits in the largest integer. So, if the largest integer needs only 2 bits, the additional memory can be 2 bits (plus the iterator/index counter). However, if the largest integer requires 100 bits, the the additional memory requires 100 bits. 

We know that numbers are not repeated more than once, so at worst case the nth number is n, which requires log2(n) bits to store. 

So, the extra memory required is actually at worst O(log(n))!

Note that if we use 32 bit integers (or really integers of any fixed size) as our tracking bits, we can pretend the memory used is constant - but really all we've done is allocated a lot of extra memory which happens to be enough.
why do you think this is the best solution? XOR\'s commutativity makes this possible with one stack allocation?
functools.reduce(operator.ixor, nums)

However, if the largest integer requires 100 bits, the the additional memory requires 100 bits. 

We know that numbers are not repeated more than once, so at worst case the nth number is n, which requires log2(n) bits to store. 

So, the extra memory required is actually at worst O(log(n))!

Note that if we use 32 bit integers (or really integers of any fixed size) as our tracking bits, we can pretend the memory used is constant - but really all we've done is allocated a lot of extra memory which happens to be enough.

    if you applay xor for all elemnet in array all the appears    twice numbers will give zeros in the result you find just a single number Let tack example

    let sort array [1,1,2,2,4]

    0 ^ 4 = 4 
   (So The Result is 4)

I didn\'t realize I could use XOR so I came up with a tricky solution that used the fact the input numbers are in [-30000,30000] range so require 2 bytes each. I reused the upper 2 bytes of each element in the array to implement an open addressing hash set with linear probing. Basically the hash set ended up being in place in the same input array without using any additional memory. I realized this was overcomplicated but I was interested to see if I could make this work. I did.

Can we solve this problem by sorting the array and doing a binary search?

Yes. you also can use Stack when you sort it. If stack is empty, just push, and if next element is as same as the head of stack, then pop the element.\nAt the end, only the unique element will remain at stack.

Hi Guys, XOR operation giving wrong output for below input array
int[] nums= [4, 1, 2, 1, 2, 4, 7, 1]
expected output: 7
but actual output : 6

Bad problem description. For people who don't know it's a bit manipulation problem, they need to specify that all inputs are powers of 2. The expected solution does not work once you start throwing in non-power-of-2 numbers, and it's not listed as a constraint anywhere.

Constraints should be updated with:

nums[i] == 2^X

It's a trick question as far as I'm concerned.
If you know how to swap 2 numbers without using a temporary variable then you will know the solution :))

but actual output : 6

Bad problem description. For people who don't know it's a bit manipulation problem, they need to specify that all inputs are powers of 2. The expected solution does not work once you start throwing in non-power-of-2 numbers, and it's not listed as a constraint anywhere.

Constraints should be updated with:

nums[i] == 2^X

It's a trick question as far as I'm concerned.
If you know how to swap 2 numbers without using a temporary variable then you will know the solution :))

A simple question for all the people with sound knowledge of logic gates , bit manipulations etc

Hi [@ArunSreekanth](/ArunSreekanth)
The following challenges requires you to find out which single number is only represented once in an array. The XOR operator is perfect for this. If you XOR every number in your array you will get the singled out number.

Here is an example:
Input: nums = [4,1,2,1,2]
4 ^ 1 = 5  
5 ^ 2 = 7
7 ^ 1 = 6
6 ^ 2 = 4
Output: 4

If you want to know more what XOR is: https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_bitwise.asp
Bitwise XOR : if corresponding number is different it gives 1 else it shows 0.
Traverse the array and XOR  all the elements, if repeated then reduces to 0 else remain ,then return.
XOR of equal numbers is 0 and XOR of 0 and any number is the number itself.

I\'ve a question : I used a hash Map to count every number from array using a for loop, which I believe it\'s O(n). Then I loop through dict keys when I find a value which a value is 1, I returned the key. It\'s also O(n) thus O(2n) which is equivalent to O(n). Is this solution fine or maybe I\'m wrong with my BigO?
hello guys, how to solve this problem by Map stls in Cpp

You can use a set. Go through the numbers, if the number is already in the set, remove it, otherwise add it. At the end of the loop, you\'ll have exactly one number left in your set so you can just return the front iterator.
XOR approach is well efficient
nice work vansh. \nCould you checkout my question above and help me with it?
class Solution:\n    def singleNumber(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:\n\t    return reduce(lambda total, el: total ^ el, nums)

hello guys, how to solve this problem by Map stls in Cpp

You can use a set. Go through the numbers, if the number is already in the set, remove it, otherwise add it. At the end of the loop, you\'ll have exactly one number left in your set so you can just return the front iterator.
